comment.author: 77603809@N02
comment._content: It looks actually like a British (Australian?) naval officer being piped aboard and greeted by the ship's officers. Note the cap badge and salute.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77603809@N02] Hmmm, we'll pass this on to our Navy history curator to double check, thanks for your comment KenjiB_48.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 49127631@N00
comment._content: Appears to be an army officer and definitely not US - the Commonwealth navies salute in a similar fashion to the Americans - not palm forward.  Possibly an army Lieutenant-Colonel - looks to be a crown with single pip on his shoulder boards.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77603809@N02] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/jadimages] Hi all, thanks for all your clues, after a bit of research we have identified the man as Lieutenant-Colonel Percy Muir McFarlane who was acting Base Commandant at Victoria Barracks in Paddington, Sydney at the time. See articles here and here for more info. It seems McFarlane had quite a distinguished military career, serving in the Boer War and both World Wars!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
